It's time for a family meeting. Can we be candid? Too often, especially in statewide campaigns, Democratic voters, particularly black voter's, desires are considered as an afterthought. We have for too long been relegated to political sharecropping. Black people have been consistently the most loyal and core base of the Democratic Party, but to what end?  Our votes are viewed as inherent, not worthy of being earned through policies that are inclusive of our nuanced needs. When pressed on our issues, we are told to wait for the rising tide to lift our boats. Why? Because political strategists can rely on Democratic voters, especially black voters, to be pragmatic. We will reliably and often regrettably hold our noses and choose the "lesser or two evils." The monied interests, wealthy elite, political gate keepers, and political kingmakers finance and elevate the candidates that they want us to choose, tell us who we need to vote for, and often shame or guilt voters into choosing that person. If we refuse to support the only option we've been given we'd be blamed for the inevitable and disastrous decline that ensues when the other party wins. They know our pragmatism won't allow us to choose the policy extremes of the Republican candidate. Therefore, that leaves us with a false choice.  Candidates like myself and others who aren't self funding millionaires or aren't in the "good ole boys" club are often written off by the establishment as unelectable because our resumes don't match those of career politicians or those who are already wealthy enough to buy the seat that they want.  This perpetuates a vicious cycle of mobilization, false promises, disappointment, disengagement, and ultimately the disenfranchisement of countless people who believed that the best choice and the only choice they had was the candidate with the most funds in their coffers.  Some of you who read this may have written our campaign off because you've decided that a win for a grassroots campaign like ours is impossible. You've decided that an unknown candidate who isn't a millionaire doesn't have a chance against an incumbent mega funded Republican in Louisiana. So you've chosen to ignore us and withhold your support while you wait for someone who checks off all your "must have" boxes. Nevertheless, this campaign is a virtuous one. We know we don't have what super funded campaigns have, but we also know what change we want to accomplish and we're committed to hearing and engaging the people who have been disenfranchised.  I hope that you will consider our platform and we hope to earn your support. Whether we raise $1 or $10 million, we aren't going ANYWHERE! We will continue fighting for the things that matter to Louisianans! We'll see you in November! Eyes on the prize.  #Pierce2020

Here's my letter to the Editor of the Advocate. Your thoughts? #ReadThis  Bill Cassidy's support for President Trump's unilateral action to assassinate Iranian General Soleimani in Iraq is aberrant and reprehensible. This order by the President inarguably placed the U.S. and our allies in the Middle East in a precarious diplomatic position and nudged us closer to an endless and expensive war with Iran. Cassidy's praise of this military action, despite the lack of evidence that Soleimani posed an imminent threat to our national security, is a clear demonstration of his willingness to forsake the safety of our soldiers and allies in the Middle East for the sake of remaining in the good graces of President whose destabilizing foreign policy agenda is questionable at best. Patriotism is not blind allegiance to the President or a political party! Patriotism is unwavering devotion to our country and the rule of law. I love my country! That's why I must hold its leadership accountable, more especially those who refuse to step beyond the confines of their required allegiance to the president and political expedience to do what is in the best interest of our national security. Two of Cassidy's fellow Republicans disagree with him concerning the President's order. Senators Mike Lee (UT) and Rand Paul (KY) maintain that there was no evidence presented during the recent Congressional briefing that Soleimani posed an imminent threat to the U.S. Neither Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, the acting Sec. of Defense, nor any other member of Trump's National Security team can provide any evidence to the public or members of Congress of an imminent threat to our troops in the region or our national security. The last time we engaged in war with another country, it was under the guise of the presence of weapons of mass destruction, which we later discovered was a lie. There has not been one shred of evidence that this assassination of Soleimani made America or our allies in the region safer. In fact, the evidence provided by our intelligence agencies lends to the contrary. Therefore, the unilateral decision made by the President to order such an act of war was both egregious and indefensible. Most Americans have no desire to engage in another endless and expensive war without verifiable evidence, especially one that was seemingly instigated for the sake of saving the presidency of one of the most corrupt and immoral Presidents we've seen in modern times. Congress must utilize its Article I powers and pass war resolutions that restrain the President's ability to order unprovoked attacks that drag our country into war for his own political gain. "Our President will start a war with Iran because he has absolutely no ability to negotiate. He‚Äôs weak and he‚Äôs ineffective. So the only way he figures that he‚Äôs going to get reelected‚Ä¶and as sure as you‚Äôre sitting there, is to start a war with Iran. I believe that he will attack Iran sometime prior to the election because he thinks that‚Äôs the only way he can get elected. Isn‚Äôt it pathetic?" - Donald J. Trump Cassidy and his Republican colleagues in Congress must find the fortitude to put partisanship and political expedience aside to hold the President accountable when his actions threaten out national security and the safety of our allies around the world.

As U.S. Senator, I vow to demand that Congress utilize its Article I powers to check the President's unilateral military responses and avoid costly wars.  I'll do this not because I hate the President, but because I love my country. #Pierce2020
